entry.title: Re: Tax statement item missing for tax code V0 in interco...
entry.content:
Thanks! Gianno I created new BP for testing this procedure, but I faced another error related to pricing when I create PO# with successful BP.

Error in net price calculation, item 000010 (Please correct) Message no. 06213

Diagnosis Possible causes: The net price is negative. Check the prices and conditions entered. An error has occurred during currency translation. Check whether the foreign currency is defined in the system. The unit of measure of an item is not allowed. Check the units of measure entered. An internal error has occurred during the price determination process. A mandatory condition type is not defined in the system.

Please contact your system administrator.

Kindly check what issue do I need to solve?

entry.title: Move system xxx to another installation
entry.content:
Hi Support,

can you reassign the system with the number DIGITS from the installation number DIGITS to the new installation number DIGITS?

Thanks


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Move system xxx to another installation
entry.content:
Dear customer,

To reassign system from one installation number to another, if both the new installation and old installation are under the same customer number or within a CCC group, then user can do the reassignment on customer side as per the self-service steps introduced in KBA 2380985. Note: user must have the Edit System Data authorization at the highest level.

if the system(s) are being moved to a different customer number (not linked in a CCC), the Super Administrator for the "old" customer number where the installation/system currently resides must create a case for component XX-SER-FORME to request the system reassignment.

More detailed information, please refer to KBA 2380985. 

Thanks and regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Custom Agentic Chatbot with SAP AI Core and Joule Studio — Part 1
entry.content:
Agentic AI Chatbots in the Enterprise Context

Enterprises today need more than a chatbot that simply provides guidelines or answers FAQs. In real business contexts, users expect AI systems that can actually take action — querying databases for insights, drafting or sending emails, and orchestrating multi-step workflows. This growing demand has led to the rise of agentic AI chatbots, which combine the familiarity of a conversational interface with the power to execute enterprise-scale tasks. While frameworks such as LlamaIndex, AutoGPT, and LangGraph enable orchestration, enterprises need robust deployment, seamless integration, and governance to run them at scale.

This blog series will walk through that journey step by step. We’ll start by building a custom agent backend, then deploy it on SAP AI Core, and finally make it directly consumable from Joule Studio — enabling business users to interact with the agent through a natural conversational interface inside Joule.

🚀 To make the process easier to follow, we’ve divided the content into three parts:

  • Part 1 — Building the Custom AI Agent Backend  (Flask + API Endpoints)
  • Part 2 — Deploying the Agent on AI Core (Docker, ServingTemplate, Deployment, Endpoint test)
  • Part 3 — Integrating the Agent into Joule Studio (Destination setup, Skill creation, testing)

By the end of this series, you will have a clear, reproducible path from

  1. Custom AI agent code in GitHub
  2. Scalable deployment on AI Core
  3. Business-ready conversational interface through Joule Studio.

 

Part 1 — Building the Custom AI Agent Backend

In this first post, we focus on the backend logic of the custom agentic chatbot. This backend is implemented with Flask and exposes REST API endpoints that support both one-shot and multi-step interactions. While one-shot calls return only the final answer, the multi-step design allows the system to expose the agent’s reasoning process step by step, improving interpretability and transparency.

Custom AI Agent Chatbot Backend Capabilities 

For demonstration purposes, the backend is designed to handle common enterprise tasks such as:

  • Structured Data Access – Query SAP HANA Database to support reporting, analytics, and decision-making.
  • Vector-based Retrieval – Search SAP HANA Vector DB to enable advanced RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) use cases.
  • Enterprise Communication – Manage enterprise emails (drafting, sending, or forwarding messages) through integration with existing systems.
  • External Information Retrieval – Fetch context from real-world services (e.g., weather updates, web search results) to enrich responses.

API Endpoint Design for Agent Orchestration

In our implementation, we adopted LangGraph as the orchestration framework. Since the agent dynamically generates a plan first, and then builds a LangGraph structure based on that plan, it was natural to split the API into multiple steps:

/v2/plan → /v2/action-graph → /v2/start-execution → /v2/continue-execution

This is just one way to design it. With a different orchestration style, you might merge steps into a single /chat endpoint or a simpler two step flow. 

Endpoint Summary:

MethodPathSummaryRequest Body
GET/v2/healthHealth check-
POST/v2/planStep 1. Generate planconversation_id, message
POST/v2/action-graphStep 2. Create action graphconversation_id
POST/v2/start-executionStep 3. Start Executionconversation_id
POST/v2/continue-executionStep 4. Complete Execution conversation_id
POST/v2/chatOne-shot chatconversation_id, message

These endpoints reflect how the workflow is divided into steps in our design. To make it more concrete, here's a minimal Flask example showing how each endpoint might look in practice.

Example Flask Code:

from flask import Flask, request, jsonify
import uuid

app = Flask(__name__)

# Health check
@app.route('/v2/health', methods=['GET'])
def health_check():
    return jsonify({"status": "healthy"})

# Step 1: Plan generation
@app.route('/v2/plan', methods=['POST'])
def generate_plan():
    """
    Example route for generating a plan.
    - Replace the stub logic with your own planner (LLM, LangGraph, rule-based, etc.).
    - Store the plan into session or external state manager if needed.
    """
    data = request.json or {}
    message = data.get('message','')
    session_id = data.get('conversation_id') or f"session-{uuid.uuid4().hex[:8]}"

    if not message:
        return jsonify({'error': 'Message is required'}), 400

    # TODO: Call planning logic here

    return jsonify({"conversation_id": session_id,
                    "type": "plan_generated",
                    "content": "<example plan object>"})

# Step 2: Action graph creation
@app.route('/v2/action-graph', methods=['POST'])
def generate_action_graph():
    """
    Example route for generating an action graph.
    - Replace with your real plan → graph transformation.
    - Retrieve the plan from session or agent manager before creating the graph.
    """
    data = request.json or {}
    session_id = data.get('conversation_id')
    if not session_id:
        return jsonify({'error':'conversation_id is required'}), 400

    # TODO: Get planning state > Implement graph creation logic here

    return jsonify({"conversation_id": session_id,
                    "type": "action_graph_generated",
                    "content": "<example content you want to show user>"})

# Step 3: Start execution
@app.route('/v2/start-execution', methods=['POST'])
def start_execution():
    """
    Example route for starting execution.
    - Replace with logic to execute the first node of the action graph.
    """
    data = request.json or {}
    session_id = data.get('conversation_id')
    if not session_id:
        return jsonify({'error':'conversation_id is required'}), 400

    # TODO: Get action graph > execute the first node of the graph

    return jsonify({"conversation_id": session_id,
                    "type": "execution_started",
                    "content": "<example content you want to show user>"})

# Step 4: Continue execution
@app.route('/v2/continue-execution', methods=['POST'])
def continue_execution():
    """
    Example route for continuing execution.
    - Replace with logic to execute remaining nodes and return the final response.
    """
    data = request.json or {}
    session_id = data.get('conversation_id')
    if not session_id:
        return jsonify({'error':'conversation_id is required'}), 400

    # TODO: Get action graph > execute remaining nodes and return final response

    return jsonify({"conversation_id": session_id,
                    "type": "execution_complete",
                    "content": "<example content you want to show user>"})

# One-shot chat
@app.route('/v2/chat', methods=['POST'])
def chat():
    """
    Example route for one-shot chat.
    - Replace with your pipeline that runs plan → graph → execution in one step.
    """
    data = request.json or {}
    message = data.get('message', '')
    session_id = data.get('conversation_id')  # use conversation_id as session_id

    # TODO: Process agent pipeline here all at once

    return jsonify({"conversation_id": session_id,
                    "type": "execution_complete",
                    "content": "<example content you want to show user>"})

if __name__ == '__main__':
    app.run(host="0.0.0.0", port=5000)

⚠️Note: this is only an example. Replace the TODO sections with your own orchestration logic.

With this backend in place, we now have a clear foundation for orchesting multi-step agent workflows, from plan generation to action execution, all exposed via REST APIs.

 

👉In the next part, we'll take this custom agent backend and deploy it on SAP AI Core: packaging the Flask service into a Docker container, creating a ServingTemplate, and exposing it as a production-ready endpoint.

entry.title: Revenue recognition key EPMFC EPPM (Project Management) module in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition.
entry.content:
I have a question about the EPPM (Project Management) module in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition. With the revenue recognition key EPMFC, revenue is recognized based on the cost-based percentage-of-completion method. When actual costs exceed planned costs, can the progress rate exceed 100% and be recognized accordingly? Or does the progress rate cap at 100% even if actual costs surpass planned costs?

Examples:
- When planned cost = actual cost:
Planned cost 500, actual cost 500, revenue 1,000 (100%)
- When planned cost > actual cost:
Planned cost 500, actual cost 250, revenue 500 (50%)
- Questioned case: when planned cost < actual cost:
Is it planned cost 500, actual cost 1,000, revenue 1,000 (100%), or
planned cost 500, actual cost 1,000, revenue 2,000 (200%)?

entry.title: Posting of Recognized Revenue for Cost‑Based Percentage‑of‑Completion Revenue Projects
entry.content:
Regarding Project Sales (4I9) and Event-Based Revenue Recognition (4GQ) in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition, we have configured a revenue-bearing project and set the revenue recognition key to EPMFC (cost-based percentage of completion). Recognized Cost of Sales (Recognized COS) has been posted without issues, but Recognized Revenue is still not being posted. Could you help us identify the cause?

With Planned COS of 10,000,000 JPY and Recognized COS of 5,000,000 JPY, the percentage of completion should be 50%, and Recognized Revenue should be 10,000,000 JPY.

Options:

 

WHERE clause can not be used on aggregate functions

 

HAVING clause can not be used on aggregate function.

 

Both WHERE and HAVING clause can not be used on aggregate functions

 

Both WHERE and HAVING clause can be used on aggregate functions

entry.title: SAP Public Cloud Report Formatting (Financial Statements / Dynamic Reporting)
entry.content:
Dear All,

Could you please confirm how we can develop custom forms in the Public Cloud environment similar to what we are used to in RISE or On-Prem solutions — where we typically utilize a custom driver program to call custom Adobe Forms?

From what I understand, the functionality in Public Cloud seems to be limited to formatting existing forms by copying them or adding a few additional fields. However, I have the following specific requirements which involve more advanced formatting and development capabilities:

  1. Development of a New Custom Program:
    Ability to create and execute a completely new program that displays a custom Adobe Form, without attaching it to or replacing with any standard form.

  2. Formatting Financial Statements:
    The current formats for Balance Sheet and Cash Flow statements are missing key formatting elements (e.g., bold or italic headings). We need to apply advanced formatting to improve readability and presentation.

  3. Displaying Dynamic Images in Forms:
    Requirement to dynamically display images (e.g., product return images, reflecting damages) within delivery or return sales order forms, after uploading them to a repository or storage area in Public Cloud.

entry.title: ADDING AND REMOVING MASS PROCESSING FUNCTIONS IN COHV
entry.content:
ACTIVATING MASS PROCESSING FUNCTIONS IN COHV

In some systems some functions like set deletion flag will not be active in cohv .We can activate the missing functions by following the below steps .we can also remove the functions in cohv. 

Steps for activating deletion flag:

Go to Tcode  COISL and select PPIOH000(order headers) and click on mass processing functions

 

 

Then goto edit and then to New entries and add deletion flag and save the tr and move to testing or qas

after moving TR to  testing we can check the set to deletion flag functionality in cohv .AS you can see its now active and can be used for mass processing orders

set deletion flag is now available in cohv.

If the requirement is to remove deletion flag we can repeat the same steps 

In COISL Tcode select PPIOH000(ORDER HEADERS) and click on  Mass processing functions.

select deletion flag mass processing functions  and click on delete and save the tr .

after moving the tr to dev you can see in cohv that the set deletion flag indicator will not be  available.

 

CONCLUSION:

By following above steps we can activate or remove mass processing functions based on requirement .Mass processing functions are highly useful and as these are readily available will be useful to meet the client requirement and to avoid custom development.

entry.title: Reusing Data Nodes to Display a Table More Than Once in Adobe Forms
entry.content:
Sometimes the developers come across a situation where they need to use the same data node more than once in the SAP adobe form layout. This seems to be simple but just merely copy pasting the same table in the layout won't print the data again because the data node can be consumed only once i.e. it can have only 1:1 relation with the table. But displaying the data again on the layout can be achieved with the help of scripting language(in my case I prefer Javascript).

Assumption:- You have already created the Adobe Form and implemented the relevant ABAP logic to fetch data into an internal table for display in the layout output.

Scenario

For simplicity, let’s select a small dataset from the MARA table and display it in the Adobe Form layout.

The following steps were followed to create this example:

  1. A structure and a global internal table were defined to hold the data.



  2. A simple SELECT query was written to fetch data from MARA into the internal table.


  3. The internal table was then bound to a data node in the layout to print the records.

Now, the data node has been used in the layout to print the records. The internal table has been put on the design view page in order to see the output. 

Let's generate the pdf and see the output. We can see that the pdf is generated and it is printing all the 20 records.

Challenge

Now, let’s assume we need to print only MATNR, MBRSH, and MEINS as a second table.

To achieve this, we created another table (say, GT_MARA_1) in the layout and bound it to the same data node as GT_MARA, but restricted the fields.

However, when we generated the PDF, the second table did not print any data, even though the correct binding was done.


 

Solution

Reusing the same data node requires a slightly different approach. Below are the steps to make it work:


Step 1:- 
Remove all the bindings from the second table (GT_MARA_1).

 

Step 2:- 

Wrap GT_MARA_1 inside a repeating subform and mark it as Repeat Subform for Each Data Item.

 

Step 3:-

Create an instance of the subform (say Sub1) for each record of GT_MARA.

To do this:

  • Wrap Sub1 inside another subform called ParentSubform.

  • Write a JavaScript snippet in the Calculate event of ParentSubform to dynamically create instances.

  • Ensure that Repeat Subform for Each Data Item is unchecked for ParentSubform.

 

Step 4:- 

Write JavaScript at the field level to fetch values from GT_MARA for each index.
For example, for fields MATNR, MBRSH, and MEINS, write JS code that accesses the data from GT_MARA row by row.



Step 5:-

Run the PDF.
You’ll notice that the output is correct, but the header row of GT_MARA_1 is repeated for every record.

Step 6:- 

Suppress the repeated header using a small JavaScript snippet in the Calculate event of the header.

 

Step 7:-
Generate the PDF again.
Now the second table prints correctly with a single header and the expected data.



Explanation of the Javascript 

Field-level code (example: MATNR):

var oFields = xfa.resolveNodes("GT_MARA.DATA[*].MATNR");    "-> Access to the MATNR field of GT_MARA table
var currIndex = this.parent.parent.parent.index;   "-> Get the current index of the repeating subform Sub1.

this.rawValue = oFields.item(currIndex).rawValue;  "-> Get the actual value of MATNR in GT_MARA for the current index

ParentSubform (to create instances of Sub1):

var oRecords = xfa.resolveNodes("GT_MARA.DATA[*]").length; "-> Get the total number of records in GT_MARA 
for ( var i = 0; i<=oRecords; i++ ){    " -> Iteration till the number of records of GT_MARA
if ( i > 0 ) {
this._Sub1.addInstance(1);    " Create a new instance of subform Sub1 for each iteration
}
}

Header suppression (in GT_MARA_1 header):

if ( this.parent.parent.index != '0' ){
this.presence = "hidden";
}

 

Final Result

The second table (GT_MARA_1) is successfully printed using the same data node, without duplicated headers.

Conclusion

Reusing the same data node in multiple tables within an Adobe Form is not straightforward. However, with subforms and some JavaScript logic, we can achieve the desired result.

If you have other suggestions or alternative solutions to reuse the data node in Adobe Forms, feel free to share!


Thanks,
Shubham

entry.title: Regular Vendor: Single Material - Mutiple Purchase organizations - Multiple vendors
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

I have encountered a scenario where a single material is listed under multiple Purchase Organizations, which are not within the same company code, and are associated with different vendor codes. Need to activate Regular Vendor, but fails.

Please see the scenarios below:

 Scenario 1Scenario 2
Material AB123AB123
P Org10002000
VendorXYZABC
Company CodeYYYZZZ
CountryABCD

 I would like to bring to your attention an issue encountered while activating a Regular Vendor for a material across different Purchase Organizations.

Scenario:

  • I successfully activated Vendor XYZ as the Regular Vendor for Material AB123 in Purchase Organization 1000.

  • When attempting to assign Vendor ABC as the Regular Vendor for the same Material AB123 in Purchase Organization 2000, I received the following warning message:

"Up to now, supplier XYZ has been the regular supplier for this material."

  • After proceeding to save, I observed that:

    • Vendor ABC is now set as the Regular Vendor in Purchase Organization 2000.

    • However, Vendor XYZ is no longer marked as the Regular Vendor in Purchase Organization 1000.

This behavior is unexpected, as:

  • Purchase Organization 1000 and 2000 belong to different company codes.

  • Vendor XYZ and Vendor ABC are distinct and unrelated.

  • There is no organizational or master data link between the vendors or purchase organizations that should prevent simultaneous activation.

Kindly assist in analyzing and resolving this issue. Our requirement is to maintain different Regular Vendors for the same material in different Purchase Organizations, which seems to be restricted by the system currently.

entry.title: Clarification on Location and Plant Section in SAP
entry.content:
We are initiating the unification of the Location and Plant Section fields within the SAP system. To proceed effectively, we need to first understand the following:

  1. What are the purposes of the "Location" and "Plant Section" fields in SAP?
  2. What are the key differences between them?
  3. What criteria should be used to define each of them?
  4. What are the recommended steps to begin this unification task?

Your guidance on these points will help us align our approach and ensure consistency across the system.

entry.title: Re: Why is my PO not transferring to E4H with risk manage...
entry.content:
Hi Prashant,

firstly, what the log in GTS say? You can check it with  /SAPSLL/PREVDI_01.

Have you checked also table /SAPSLL/PREPDOC? If yest what about field REQUEST_STATUS in this tabl?. I have the feeling is out of the validity range that you have maintained in the LTSD setting(e.g. request tolerance days vs the delivery date in your PO.) 

Regards,

entry.title: Impact on Teams When Team Creator Becomes Deleted User in SAC
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

I have a question regarding user deletion behavior in SAP Analytics Cloud.

When a user is deleted and replaced by a "deleted user" placeholder, it is understood that folders or objects owned by that deleted user will be deleted after 90 days. However, I would like to clarify what happens in the following scenario:

- If the creator of a Team becomes a deleted user, will the Team itself or any related objects/folders also be deleted after 90 days, similar to how contents owned directly by the deleted user are handled?

I have searched the SAP Community but could not find any clear explanation or discussion about this case.

Could someone please share insights or official documentation regarding how SAC manages team ownership and deletion rules when the original team creator is deleted?

Thank you very much in advance for your support.

Best regards,

entry.title: Re: SAP Public Cloud Report Formatting (Financial Stateme...
entry.content:
Hello @adnanmaqbool 

Thank you for your questions. Here is what is specifically possible in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

New stand-alone custom form

Classic Z driver programs (SE38/NACE) are unavailable in Public Cloud.

Create a simple ABAP Cloud class that calls the SAP Forms service by Adobe and sends the PDF to a Print Queue or email.

The data source comes from a Custom CDS/OData view that is defined.SAP Community-Calling Custom Adobe form in ABAP On Cloud (Embedded Steampunk)

Financial statements formatting

For printable or PDF output, duplicate the SAP template in Maintain Form Templates. Style it using Adobe Designer with bold, italics, font sizes, and section headers.

Statement structure is guided by your Financial Statement Version / Global Accounting Hierarchies. If you require board-ready layouts, we can generate them in SAP Analytics Cloud and export to PDF/PowerPoint. SAP Help-Manage Your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition-Application Form Templates

SAP Help-Invoice Management-Adding Custom Fields to Payment List Forms

Dynamic images on forms

Add an Image (Graphic) in the Adobe template and bind it to a runtime URL or byte stream.

Photos can be saved as Attachments (A2X) via the API on the business object (such as Delivery or Return). The file reference is made available through Custom Fields and Logic, or via the form BAdI, enabling the form to display the image during printing. 

SAP Help-APIs for Warehousing-Attachments (A2X)

Proposed Next Steps

  • Confirm the first target: Delivery, Return Sales Order, or Financial Statement.
  • I will prepare the field list, outline the image binding method, and create a basic ABAP Cloud caller for the form.
  • Adjust the layout in Adobe Designer and specify recipients/channels in Output Parameter Determination (OPD).

Let me know if it help

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Report or List of attached documents in Maintenance W...
entry.content:
Hi Aliciagao
In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, direct table access is restricted, so you cannot query attachments from traditional tables. However, you have several options: Standard CDS Views – For Maintenance Orders, CDS views such as I_MaintenanceOrder and I_MaintenanceOrderOperation exist, but they do not directly expose document attachments. Attachment Service (GOS in Cloud equivalent) – In the Public Cloud, attachments are stored in the Attachment Service and exposed through APIs rather than tables. You can use: SAP API Hub → Attachments API (for business objects, including Maintenance Orders). Business Object Node: MaintenanceOrder → check attachments via A_MaintenanceOrderAttachment (if available in your release). Custom CDS View / Custom Query – You may create a custom CDS view joining: I_MaintenanceOrder I_Attachment (or its cloud equivalent, depending on release) This allows filtering per Plant. Reporting – In Fiori apps like Manage Work Orders and Notifications, you can navigate to the attachments at order level, but if you need an aggregated list, you must build a Custom Analytical Report via Custom CDS Views and Custom Analytical Queries.
 So, the answer is: No standard CDS view currently provides a full list of attached documents per Work Order. You will need to leverage either: Attachment APIs (recommended), or Custom CDS Views joining order data with attachment data.

Enquiry regarding downsizing of AWS-EC2 servers
entry.content:
Hi Team,

 

Downsizing of AWS-EC2 scale down is planned.

 

Target Systems: RDR-DB, AP, RAR-DB, IXOS-Quality

 

Related to OS settings, SAP memory parameter revision could you please advise us what are the necessary BASIS checks to be done?

 

Regards,

 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Enquiry regarding downsizing of AWS-EC2 servers
entry.content:
When planning AWS EC2 downsizing for SAP systems (DB + App + IXOS), you’ll want to ensure both OS-level and SAP BASIS-level checks are performed so that the reduced instance sizes remain stable and performant. Here’s a structured checklist:

1. OS-Level Checks

  1. CPU / Memory Usage Trends

    • Review historical workload (ST06, OS monitoring tools, CloudWatch).

    • Peak CPU utilization should not consistently exceed 70–80% after downsizing.

    • Ensure memory consumption + SAP extended memory fit into the new RAM size.

  2. Swap Configuration

    • Verify swap space meets SAP recommendation (usually 1.5x–2x physical memory up to a threshold).

    • Check /proc/meminfo and OS logs for swapping activity.

  3. Disk I/O & Filesystem

    • Check DB/data/log volumes’ IOPS usage (AWS EBS metrics).

    • Ensure I/O demand is within the new EC2/EBS limits.

    • Validate filesystem capacity (df -h) — especially for /usr/sap, /sapmnt, /oracle or /hana/data/log.

  4. Network Performance

    • Compare current bandwidth/packets with the new EC2 instance’s ENI limits.

    • Critical for DB–App server communication latency.

2. SAP Memory Parameter Checks

  1. Instance Profile Parameters (ABAP)

    • em/initial_size_MB (extended memory)

    • ztta/roll_extension (per work process memory)

    • abap/heap_area_total (heap memory cap)

    • PHYS_MEMSIZE (should reflect new physical memory, if set manually)

    • Ensure total memory sizing (Extended + Heap + Shared Buffers) < 80% of new system memory.

  2. Buffer/Cache Parameters

    • abap/buffersize, rdisp/PG_SHM, rdisp/ROLL_SHM

    • ST02 (SAP Memory buffers) → check hit ratios; avoid oversizing in downsized system.

  3. DBMS Specific

    • For RDR-DB / RAR-DB (if Oracle, HANA, SQL Server):

      • Review DB buffer/cache sizing vs. new instance memory.

      • SAP HANA: check global_allocation_limit against reduced RAM.

3. SAP Workload & Performance

  1. ST03N (Workload Analysis)

    • Peak dialog/background throughput vs. available CPU cores.

    • Batch job concurrency: review SM37 job loads during peak windows.

  2. ST02 (SAP Memory Buffers)

    • Look for swaps/expands in buffer areas.

    • Re-adjust table/buffer parameters for reduced memory footprint.

  3. SM50/SM66 (Work Process Utilization)

    • Ensure number of work processes is feasible with reduced memory.

  4. Background & Interfaces

    • Check RFC/IDoc loads, PI/XI or third-party integrations — ensure not memory-heavy.

4. AWS-Specific Considerations

  1. EC2 Instance Type Limits

    • Compare current vs. target instance type (CPU cores, memory, ENA support).

    • Ensure SAP Note-supported instance types are used.

  2. CloudWatch Alarms

    • Reconfigure thresholds for CPU, memory (via custom metrics), and disk I/O after downsizing.

  3. Elastic Load Balancer / AutoScaling (if AP servers)

    • Validate scaling policies if AP is in auto-scaling group.

5. General BASIS Preparations

  • Pre- and Post-Move Benchmark

    • Capture OS stats (vmstat, iostat, top), SAP workload (ST03N/ST02).

    • Compare after downsizing.

  • Check SAP Notes

    • SAP on AWS sizing guidelines.

    • SAP kernel & DB vendor recommendations for memory settings.

  • Test Cycle

    • Run stress tests (batch jobs, reporting) on new system size.

    • Monitor dumps (ST22), syslog (SM21), DB alerts.

entry.title: Re: Clarification on Location and Plant Section in SAP
entry.content:
Hi SMEs;

In SAP Plant Maintenance (PM), both Location and Plant Section are organizational fields used for reporting, analysis, and structuring equipment and functional locations.

However, they serve different purposes:

Purpose of the Fields:

Location: Represents the physical place where the equipment or functional location is installed (e.g., Building A, Workshop 3, Line 2). It is mainly used for technical reporting, analysis of failures by location, and geographic/physical grouping.

Plant Section: Represents the responsible organizational unit within the plant (e.g., Mechanical Team, Electrical Section, Production Unit). It is mainly used for assigning responsibility, work planning, and accountability of maintenance activities.

Key Differences: Location → "Where" the equipment is installed (physical/geographic).

Plant Section → "Who" is responsible for the equipment (organizational responsibility).

Criteria for Definition: Define Location based on physical hierarchy: building, line, workshop, area.

Define Plant Section based on responsibility: maintenance section, production department, or unit responsible for operations.

Recommended Steps for Unification: Assessment: Review current master data usage in both fields across plants.

Harmonization Rules: Define clear rules: "Location = physical place" / "Plant Section = responsible org unit".

Data Cleansing: Clean up duplicate or inconsistent entries. Governance: Establish governance rules so that master data creation follows the unified logic.

Testing: Validate with reporting and maintenance order assignments to ensure the logic works. Rollout: Apply changes systematically across all plants.

In summary: Location is “where”, Plant Section is “who”. Unification should not mean merging them into one field, but rather defining clear usage rules and cleaning data so both fields are consistent and meaningful.

entry.title: Parent/Child Vendor Relationships (Hierarchy) in Ariba
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

We are currently exploring an enhancement for one of our clients involving Parent/Child Vendor Relationships in SAP Ariba, and we would appreciate your insights or guidance on how best to approach this.

Current Setup:

  • Vendor records are created and maintained in S/4HANA via MDG, and synchronized with SAP Ariba twice daily.
  • In Ariba, each vendor is created as a standalone entry, resulting in multiple listings for the same company (e.g., Microsoft, U.S. Bank, Amazon), often representing different business units or geographies.
  • This leads to confusion during vendor selection, as users must manually identify the correct vendor from a long list.

Business Requirement:

  • Display only a single vendor option (parent) during selection in Ariba Buying.
  • Enable spend reporting to be consolidated across all associated child vendors.

Request for Guidance:

  • Is there a native capability in Ariba to support parent/child vendor relationships?
  • If not, are there any recommended configurations, workarounds, or best practices to achieve this?
  • Has anyone implemented a similar solution or enhancement?

Any documentation, experience, or suggestions would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you in advance for your support!
SAP Ariba Spend Analysis SAP Ariba Invoice Management , SAP Ariba Sourcing SAP Ariba Supplier Risk SAP Ariba Buying and Invoicing SAP Supplier Lifecycle Management

entry.title: Re: Wear Monitoring Measurement Maintenance Plans/Counters
entry.content:
Hi  Kaejae;
Of course, the explanation I have given below is brief and very concise. In this regard, SAP has left the consultants' hands very full in terms of measurement points.

In SAP PM, the behavior you are facing is standard for counter-based maintenance plans. By default, the system schedules the next call based on multiples of the cycle (180, 360, 540, etc.) unless you reset the plan.

To achieve your requirement — triggering every time the counter reaches 180 units regardless of when the last change-out occurred — you have two main options:

1-Use a Performance-Based Maintenance Plan with Reset Counter Technique (Measuring Point Reset):

Instead of letting the counter accumulate indefinitely, use the “Reset Counter” function when the equipment is replaced.

This way, the maintenance plan always starts counting from zero again, and the next due will always be at 180.

Important: you must configure the measuring point as "Counter with Reset" (not cumulative total).

2-Alternative: Use a Condition-Based Strategy Plan with Measurement Documents:

Instead of relying purely on counters, define a single-cycle strategy plan linked to the wear measuring point.

In this case, the plan evaluates the latest measurement documents, and as soon as the threshold (180) is crossed, a work order will be generated.

This avoids misalignment when the actual change-out happens later (e.g., at 195 or 225).

Recommendation:
The cleanest approach is to use Reset Counter at each change-out. That way, your cycle is always 0 → 180, independent of the previous readings. If you cannot reset the counter, then condition-based maintenance with measurement documents and threshold values is the better option.

 

Step 1: Create Measuring Point (Wear Counter)

TCode: `IK01` (Create Measuring Point)
SPRO Path:
`Plant Maintenance and Customer Service → Master Data in Plant Maintenance and Customer Service → Technical Objects → Measuring Points and Counters → Create Measuring Point`

Key Settings:

Assign Measuring Point to Equipment or Functional Location.
Measuring Point Category → Counter (with reset option) .
Define Unit of Measurement (e.g., mm, hr, cycle).
Activate Reset Counter Allowed to enable reset after each change out.

my Scenario

Step 2: Create Maintenance Item

TCode: `IP41` (Create Maintenance Item)
SPRO Path:
`Plant Maintenance and Customer Service → Maintenance and Service Processing → Maintenance Plans, Work Scheduling → Maintenance and Service Items → Create Maintenance Item`

Key Settings:

Link the Equipment and Measuring Point.
Define Cycle = 180 (e.g., 180 mm, 180 hours, etc.).

 

Step 3: Create Counter Based Maintenance Plan

TCode: `IP42` (Create Maintenance Plan)
SPRO Path:
`Plant Maintenance and Customer Service → Maintenance and Service Processing → Maintenance Plans, Work Scheduling → Maintenance Plans → Create Single Cycle Plan`

Key Settings:

Choose Counter Based Strategy .
Assign the Maintenance Item created in Step 2.
Cycle Length = 180.
Scheduling Indicator = Performance Based .

 

Step 4: Reset Counter During Change Out

TCode: `IK11` (Create Measurement Document)
When the part/equipment is changed, create a Measurement Document and reset the counter.
The counter will restart from zero → next trigger will again be at 180.

 

Step 5: Testing the Scenario

1. Daily Reading Entry (Measurement Document):

`IK11` → enter values (e.g., 170 → 175 → 180).
At ≥180, system generates a Maintenance Call .

2. Generate Maintenance Order:

After reaching 180, system automatically creates a PM Order.
Use `IP10` to schedule and process the plan.

3. After Change Out:

Record reset in WO completion (via IK11).
Counter starts at zero → next WO triggers at 180 again.

Alternative: Condition Based Maintenance

If you don’t want to reset counters and only want to trigger whenever the reading exceeds 180:

SPRO Path:
`Plant Maintenance and Customer Service → Maintenance and Service Processing → Maintenance Plans, Work Scheduling → Condition Based Maintenance → Define Threshold Values`
Define Threshold = 180.
System will trigger WO whenever the reading ≥180 (no reset needed).

Outcome:

Option 1 (Counter with Reset): Clean cycle → every 180 the system triggers a WO.
Option 2 (Condition Based): WO triggered each time the measurement exceeds the defined threshold (180), even without resetting.

entry.title: Manual Leave Collection for Employees/ Converting AL balance to a custom Overseas Leave Quota
entry.content:
Namaste Everyone,
In this blog we shall understand a challenge we faced in Time Off –

Manual Leave Collection for Employees/ Converting Annual Leave balance to a custom Overseas Leave Quota

Problem Statement:

  • Employees’ Annual Leave balance for the current year will be converted to a Leave Quota called Overseas Leave Quota should they wish to have it and are approved to do so by 31 December. Employees will be able to select to convert a fraction / full Annual Leaves to Overseas Leave during the month of December.
  • The selected number will be deducted from Annual Leave balance and shall be used by an employee in the upcoming year.

Example: Overseas leave collected from Annual Leaves in Dec 2025 can be utilized by an employee in entire year of 2026. 

Problem Transformation in SAP/SF Consulting Terms:

Currently, we do not have a pre-built mechanism to create manual entries for Leave Quotas to be exchanged-Annual Leave Quota to Any Quota for example an Overseas Leave Quota. 

Prerequisites:

One should know how Time Accounts are created, Calendars, etc are run & where one places an Interim Update rule.

Solution Proposed:

We introduced:

  • Custom MDF portlet for employees to enter the quantity of leaves they wish to transform into Overseas Quota Leaves from Annual Leave Balance.
  • We shall run interim updates on Annual Leave Balance Quotas and then on Overseas Leave Quota to convert the quantity of leaves.
  • We will create a custom field in Time Account called: “BALANCE AT ACCOUNT CLOSING FOR OVERSEAS LEAVE “– which shall store the leave balance which we placed in MDF into Annual Leave Quota Time Account, let’s call it via INTERIM UPDATE – A run.
  • This BALANCE shall be carried forward to Overseas Leave Quota with another job called – INTERIM UPDATE – B run.
  • We can see this Balance in our Time Accounts for Overseas Leave Quotas and on next year’s Absences screen.

Flowchart:

Employee enters leave quantity 

in Custom MDF Portlet 

(Annual Leave → Overseas Quota Leave)

         ↓

 Interim Update – A run

Updates Annual Leave Balance Quota

and transfers to

         ↓

 BALANCE AT ACCOUNT CLOSING FOR OVERSEAS LEAVE

(custom field in Time Account)

         ↓

 Interim Update – B run

Transfers BALANCE to Overseas Leave Quota

         ↓

 Final BALANCE visible in

Time Accounts (Overseas Leave Quota)

& also, in Next Year’s Absence Screen

 

Technical Build:

  1. We have created a simple effective dated MDF to capture quantity of leaves that an employee wishes to be deducted from Annual leaves balances to be stored in Overseas Leave Quota for the next year.

                We shall give the required details here.

 

  1. While we toggle to Annual Leave Quota, we can see the number of initial Annual Leaves.

 

  1. We shall, now, run an “Interim Update – A” to fetch the value put in MDF to be placed in a custom field “BALANCE AT ACCOUNT CLOSING FOR OVERSEAS LEAVE “in Time Account for Annual Leave Quota.

 

  Interim Update rule – A (Placed in Interim Update Section of Annual Leave Quota Time Account) can be seen as below:

 

 

  1. We must send this Balance to Overseas Leave Quota now.

We shall run Interim Update - B (Placed in Interim Update section of Overseas Leave Time Account)

 

 

  1. Upon running Interim Update -2 , we can see that the Annual leave balance has been reduced by 12.

 

Simultaneously, Overseas Leave Quota has added 12 days in it for next year 2026

 

  1. We can, now, toggle to Absence page and claim our leaves for the next year and check if they are coming up.

 In the manner above, we were able to provide solution to this challenging problem by use of a mixed bag of Interim rules and a lot of Consulting know-how. 

Hope you find it helpful!

Thanks,

Rahul VijayKiran Mattoo

entry.title: Re: what is the meaning of packaging material type when m...
entry.content:
Hello @maggie2 

The packaging material type in S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition groups packaging materials and controls handling-unit (HU) behaviour, for example, number assignment rules, closed/open handling, and label printing SAP Help-Supply Chain Packaging Material

How to read your list

Car = Carton, Pal = Pallet, WB = Wood box/wire basket (generic box/basket), Auxiliary Pack Mat = slip-sheets, fillers, lids, etc. SAP Help Portal-SAP Extended Warehouse Management (SAP EWM)

Int./Ext. = number assignment allows internal and/or external HU numbers

SSCC (Serial Shipping Container Code) is supported for HU identification in Cloud SAP Help-Handling Unit Identification

Auxiliary packaging materials such as lids, fillers, and slip-sheets are part of the Cloud packing model. SAP Help Portal-Packing

Your codes, decoded

SP11 – Carton, internal/external numbering, closed

SP12 – Carton, external numbering, closed

SP13 – Carton, SSCC numbering, closed

SP14 – Carton, GTL numbering, closed

SP21 – Pallet, internal/external, open

SP22 – Pallet, external, open

SP23 – Pallet, SSCC, open

SP24 – Pallet, GTL, open

SP31 – Box/Basket, internal/external, closed

SP32 – Box/Basket, external, closed

SP33 – Box/Basket, SSCC, closed

SP34 – Box/Basket, GTL, closed

SP41 – Auxiliary packaging material (filler, lid, slip sheet, and others)

Practical tip for the migration template (Product)

Map packaging materials material type VERP/LEIH to the appropriate SP type by considering the container form (carton, pallet, or box), the numbering scheme (internal, external, SSCC, GTL), and whether it needs to be closed or open.

Let me know if you need further information

With regards

Chuma

For photos or labels later, SSCC/GTL types allow you to print compliant IDs on HU labels.

entry.title: Re: Clarification on Location and Plant Section in SAP
entry.content:
hello ;
Thank you for your expert and interesting discussion. Your seriousness and follow-up speak volumes about your expertise.
In SAP S/4HANA, the usage of Location, Plant Section, and Work Center within functional location master data can be differentiated as follows:

Work Center: Indicates the organizational unit responsible for performing the work (e.g., maintenance department, production team). It is linked to capacity planning, scheduling, and cost allocation.

Location: Refers to the physical location of the technical object (e.g., building, area, shop floor). It is primarily used for reporting, filtering, and structuring technical objects by their physical placement.

Plant Section: This field is intended to represent a subdivision within the plant, typically used to indicate organizational responsibility for a specific area of operations or equipment within the plant (e.g., mechanical section, utilities, or packaging area).

Unlike the Work Center, which is used in work execution, Plant Section is more for classification and responsibility mapping in master data.

In practice:

Use Work Center for operational responsibility (who performs the work).

Use Plant Section for organizational responsibility within the plant (which section of the plant owns or oversees the equipment).

Use Location for the physical/geographical placement of the equipment.

Regarding global references:

SAP generally follows ISO 14224 (Petroleum, petrochemical and natural gas industries – Collection and exchange of reliability and maintenance data for equipment) where organizational responsibility and location are distinguished.

Internal company guidelines or RACI responsibility matrices are often mapped to these fields.

Best practice: Clearly define in your company maintenance policy how each field should be used, to ensure consistency across plants.

entry.title: Re: CAP - Use i18n for Error Messages
entry.content:
Hi @hoandreasm,

Great, that’s an improvement!
Could you please check the Network tab in your browser’s developer console to see whether the browser is trying to load the .properties files in the browser’s language?

A few months ago, I created a small CAP (Node.js) project to explore some capabilities. In that project, I implemented translations for all app texts, including error messages from the service handlers. You can take a look at it, it might help you troubleshoot the issue: GitHub project.
I tested it this morning with my browser set to English: after cloning the repo, running npm install, and starting the app with cds watch, everything loaded in English as expected.
To simulate an error, you can select a "CANCELLED" flight and add a delay to it.
Then, I switched my browser language to French, restarted it, relaunched the app and all texts appeared in French.

I hope this helps you identify where your issue might be coming from!

Best regards,
Valentin

entry.title: DELINS IDoc: How can system accept different time daily schedule line
entry.content:
We receive inbound DELINS IDoc and for one location, it wants to accept time specific daily schedule lines for SDSA.  Currently, the logic in IDOC_INPUT_DELINS overwrites the existing daily schedule line if the incoming IDoc has the same date even if the time and quantity is different.  In manual VA32 transaction, it allows multiple daily schedule line for the same date and different time.  But not for the inbound IDoc. 

For example, if the SDSA has existing daily schedule line 19.09.2025 time 04:00 with quantity 300 ST, and then IDoc segment field E1EDP16-EDATUV 19.09.2025, E1EDP16-EZEIT 16:00 with quantity E1EDP16-WMENG 150 ST.  The SDSA schedule line will be updated to 19.09.2025 16:00 150 ST.  Our expectation is the SDSA should have 2 daily lines for the date 19.09.2025.

I'm not sure if this is a bug but in case, is there a note on this?  Or can this be solved by customizing or a user-exit/enhancement needs to be implemented in function module IDOC_INPUT_DELINS?
